prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA - I took my son to a homeless shelter because he wouldn't get a job
My son was 23 when this happened but I've always felt guilty about it. This was a few years ago. 

My son was one of those kids who just wanted to lay around and pig out and play video games. He could never keep a job for very long. He had friends over every weekend and contributed nothing. Every time I tried to talk to him about getting a job he would say "Oh mom" and go to his room and shut the door.

Ever since he was 17 I have told him he needs to think about a trade school he wants to attend or a skill he wants to master for his future. He wasn't college material but that's ok. I learned a trade and it has been a good living for me so I was fine with him going the trade route too.

He learned bartending and only worked one bartending job for 6 months until the bar went out of business. He worked other dumb jobs for a few weeks then would quit or get fired. This went on for years.

Finally I had had enough. I told him I was selling the house and moving a half hour away and he wasn't coming with me so he better make plans.

He kept lollygagging for another year while potential buyers came around as constant reminders that soon the house will be sold.

Then it sold and I bought another. Immediately after it sold I called the homeless shelter and found out they only had four beds for single males and were full. I called every day until one day there was an opening. 

I threw my son's shit in the car and told him we are going to the shelter. He didn't argue or fight because he knew this day was coming. I think at first he didn't believe I would really do it but when it came time he wasn't surprised.

At the shelter I told him I love him but he has to learn to get on by himself now. It was the hardest thing I had ever done. But I knew if I let him live with me it would be more of the same.

A few weeks later I moved into my new home. He called and begged to come live with me. I said under one condition. He go to barber school (I am a barber).

He agreed and came home and went to barber school and is now a barber and is living on his own. 

Was there a better way to do this than to send him to a shelter? I never heard of other parents having to resort to this. How do other's get rid of adult kids? AITA
"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let me try to figure this out. The user is asking if the parent who sent their 23-year-old son to a homeless shelter is in the wrong. The parent feels guilty but did it to force the son to become independent. The son wasn't working, was staying at home, and the parent decided to move away, leading to this action.

First, I need to consider the son's age. At 23, he's an adult, so the parent isn't legally obligated to support him anymore. But sending him to a homeless shelter seems extreme. The parent tried to get him to go to trade school, he had some jobs but didn't last. The parent's final step was moving away and then sending him to the shelter when the house sold.

Is there a better way? Maybe setting up boundaries without involving a shelter. Like requiring him to pay rent, cutting off financial help, or encouraging him to find work with more support. The parent did eventually let him come back on the condition of going to barber school, which worked out. But using a homeless shelter might have been traumatic and could be seen as cruel, even if the intention was good.

However, the parent's actions did lead to the son becoming independent. The question is whether the method was appropriate. Different people have different views on parenting. Some might say the parent was too harsh, others might think it was necessary to break the cycle. The parent did mention feeling guilty, which shows they care. 

Also, considering the shelter situation—maybe the parent didn't have other options. If the son refused to leave on his own, maybe this was a last resort. But there might be other resources or support systems they could have used instead. 

In terms of AITA (Am I the Asshole), the community often looks at intent and consequences. The intent here was to help the son become independent, which is a positive goal. The method was harsh but effective. However, using a homeless shelter might be crossing a line, even if it worked. The parent could be seen as not providing a safety net when the son needed it, but also as pushing him to grow up. 

I think there's a balance. The parent isn't in the wrong because they were trying to help their son become self-sufficient, but the method might be questionable. But since the son eventually succeeded, maybe the answer is No (B). However, the use of the shelter might be seen as too extreme, making the parent in the wrong (A). 

But the user thinks the author isn't in the wrong. Maybe the key is that the parent had tried everything else and the son wasn't responding. In that case, sending him to the shelter was a last resort. So the answer might be B.
